Problem:
Consider a system where the temperature distribution in a rod over time is described by the heat equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = k \\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial x^2}\\), where k is the thermal diffusivity. We explore the effects of a transformation defined by \\(g(u) = u + c\\) where c is a constant offset applied to the temperature distribution.

If an additional transformation \\( h(u) = ae^{bx}u \\) is applied as an intervention at a certain time \\( t_1 \\) where a and b are constants, will the temperature distribution at any point \\( x \\) at a time T > t_1 depend solely on the original distribution and not on the constant c?
Explanation: The intervention with \\( h(u) \\) at time \\( t_1 \\) changes the evolution dynamics of the system, making it depend on the transformed state \\( u'(x,t_1) = u(x,t_1) + c \\). Therefore, the final temperature profile at time T will not only rely on the original distribution but also on the value of the constant c and the effects of the transformation \\( h(u) \\).
